title: Scottish Ghost Stories
author: O'Donnell, Elliott
snippet: Many are the stories that have from time to time been circulated withregard to the haunting of the Pass of Killiecrankie by phantomsoldiers, but I do not think there is any stranger story than thatrelated to me, some years ago, by a lady who declared she had actuallywitnessed the phenomena.

title: Scottish Ghost Stories
author: O'Donnell, Elliott
snippet: Many are the stories that have from time to time been circulated withregard to the haunting of the Pass of Killiecrankie by phantomsoldiers, but I do not think there is any stranger story than thatrelated to me, some years ago, by a lady who declared she had actuallywitnessed the phenomena.

title: Europe from May to December,
author: Williams, Rudolph.
snippet: The Pass of Killiecrankie is in a deep and very romantic ravine, in the bottom of which runs very swiftly, amoug great rocks, the Tummel River.

title: Leaves from the journal of our life in the Highlands, from 1848 to 1861.
author: Victoria
snippet: We passed Pitlochrie, a small village, Faskally, a very pretty place of Mr. Butter's, to the left, and then came to the Pass of Killiecrankie, which is quite magnificent ; the road winds along it, and you look down a great height, all wooded on both sides ; the Garry rolling below it.

title: Leaves from the journal of our life in the Highlands, from 1848 to 1861.
author: Victoria
snippet: There was again a shower,but it cleared when we came in sight oi Ben-y-Ghla, and the splendid Pass of Killiecrankie,which, with the birch all golden — not, as on Deeside, bereft of leaves — looked very beautiful.

title: Leaves from the journal of our life in the Highlands, from 1848 to 1861.
author: Victoria
snippet: We drove to thePass of Killiecrankie, which looked in its greatestbeauty and splendor, and appeared quite closed,so that one could not imagine how one was to getout of it.

title: Leaves from the journal of our life in the Highlands, from 1848 to 1861 :
author: Victoria
snippet: We droveto the Pass of Killiecrankie, which looked in itsgreatest beauty and splendour, and appeared quiteclosed, so that one could not imagine how one wasto get out of it.

title: Leaves from the journal of our life in the Highlands, from 1848 to 1861 :
author: Victoria
snippet: We passed Pitlochrie, a small village, Faskally,a very pretty place of Mr. Butter's, to the left, andthen came to the Pass of Killiecrankie, which isquite magnificent ; the road winds along it, andyou look down a great height, all wooded on bothsides ; the Garry rolling below it.

title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: If the visitor return to the same point, he should take a new path to the left, which conducts over a wooded eminence, displaying a most magnificent and unexpected view of the Pass of Killiecrankie.

title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: From no other point can an adequate idea be obtained of that screen of hills which bounds the eastern side of this valley ; extending from the Falls of the Bruar to Ben Vracky, and including the fine wooded hill of Urrard, the rich grounds of Lude,and the remainder of this bold and highly ornamented declivity, as far as the grey obscure fissure that forms the Pass of Killiecrankie.

title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: The summit of this hill, which is readily accessible even on horseback, presents, as in a camera obscura, all the complicated parts of the vale of Blair, and every intricacy of its highly ornamented grounds, with the rich course of the Garry, from the brown moors of Dalnacardoch down to the Pass of Killiecrankie.

title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: In September 1844, Her Majesty sojourned for nearly three weeks at Blair Castle, visiting the Falls of Bruar, the Pass of Killiecrankie, the Falls of Tummel, and the other picturesque scenery with which the neighbourhood abounds.

title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: Loch and Falls of Tummel form an easy and agreeable excursion  from Pitlocbrie, and may be reached either by crossing the bridge here or by striking ofi' the north road at the bridge of Garry, near the entrance to the Pass of Killiecrankie.

title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: Pass of Killiecrankie . . 17 „

title: A year in Europe,
author: Moore, Walter William
snippet: Farther down we enjoyed the picturesqueness  of the Pass of Killiecrankie, but it was the history here rather than the scenery which interested us, for it was here that Claverhouse, the stony-hearted persecutor of the Covenanters, fought and won his last battle, but lost his own life.

title: A year in Europe,
author: Moore, Walter William
snippet: Farther down we enjoyed the picturesqueness  of the Pass of Killiecrankie, but it was the history here rather than the scenery which interested us, for it was here that Claverhouse, the stony-hearted persecutor of the Covenanters, fought and won his last battle, but lost his own life.

title: An American four-in-hand in Britain /
author: Carnegie, Andrew
snippet: The first of all our glens is the Pass of Killiecrankie,  that famous defile which gave its name to the battle that proved so fatal to the Stuarts, for the victory won there by the adherents of the so-called James VII.

title: An American four-in-hand in Britain /
author: Carnegie, Andrew
snippet: Pass of Killiecrankie.

title: The Diamond Rose: a life of love and duty.
author: Tytler, Sarah
snippet: In the last generation, did not a philosophical and horticultural lord whistle and prunehis trees after the announcement on one day of thedeath of his two sons ? and did not my LordViscount Dundee's widow wed my Lord Kilsyth,whose pistol, according to rumour, spun out thesilver bullet which stretched the persecutor dead inthe Pass of Killiecrankie?

title: Tales of a Grandfather ... [ser. 1-3.] With notes.
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: In this celebrated defile, called the Pass of Killiecrankie, the road runs forseveral miles along the banks of a furious river, called the Garry, which ragesbelow, amongst cataracts and 'water-falls, which the eye can scarcely discern,while a series of precipices and wooded mountains rise on the other hand ; theroad itself is the only mode of access through the glen, and along the valleywhich lies at its northern extremity.

title: The Prose Works of Sir Walter Scott. (Supplementary volume: containing notes, historical and illustrative, by the author, glossary, etc.)
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: In this celebrated defile, called the Pass of Killiecrankie, the road runs for several mdes along thebanks of a furious river, called the Garry, whichrages below, amongst cataracts and water-falls whichthe eye can scarcely discern, while a series of precipices and wooded mountains rise on the other hand;and the road itself is the only mode of access throughthe glen, and along the valley which hes at its northern extremity.
